sec.p: Type of publication identifier or the organization or system that defined the identifier.
This attribute is used in several contexts:

list-item.p: Inside a bibliographic citation element (such as <mixed-citation> or <element-citation>), for example, on the <pub-id> element, which identifies a publication cited in a bibliographic reference list;
On an object identifier element (<object-id>), which can act as an identifier for any number of different elements.

caption.title: In element <pub-id>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: (Bioinformatics) a unique identifier given to a DNA or protein sequence record for tracking the sequence record and the associated sequence over time in a data repository.
Archival Resource Key — a Uniform Resource Locator (URL) containing the word “ark” that is a multi-purpose identifier for information objects of any type
Generic article accession identifier for interchange and retrieval between archives.
Obsolete PDB/CCDC identifier (may be present on older articles).
Handle identifier, part of the Handle System for assigning, managing, and resolving persistent identifiers for digital objects and other resources on the Internet
None of the named identifiers in this list.

The original “Publisher Item Identifier” (PII) was a system to provide unique and concise identification for individual published documents with a highly specified string. The PII specification is no longer in common use (2010).
Publisher’s identifier, such as an “article-id”, “artnum”, “identifier”, “article-number”, “pub-id”, etc.

Serial Item and Contribution Identifier (An older ANSI/NISO Z39.56 code to uniquely identify volumes, journal articles, or other parts of a periodical. A journal article may have more than one SICI, for example, one for a print version and another for an electronic version.).
The official number of a standard, from a standards body such as ISO, NISO, IEEE, ASME, and others, for example, “Z39.96-2015”.

caption.title: In elements <issue-id> and <volume-id>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The type of identifier of the cited objects, which may be a standard, book, journal article, etc. This attribute is typically used to name the type of identifier (such as “doi”) or the name of the organization or type of organization that created the identifier (“ISO” or “archive”).

caption.title: In element <object-id>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The type of identifier assigned to an internal structure such as a figure or boxed text (typically, a “doi”, but the attribute may name the organization that created the identifier, “CEN”, or the type of organization that created the identifier, “reseller”).

sec.p: Combined form of both the type and format of publication, combined. This attribute comes from an older version of JATS; Deprecated in NISO STS.

caption.title: In elements <issn> and <pub-date>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Precombined type and format of the document. Best Practice is not to use this attribute. See Remarks above.

sec.p: Format or medium of the document (for example, “print”). This element has several uses:

list-item.p: to describe the format/medium of a standards document for a publication date or other lifecycle date (<release-date>) or for an organization-specific lifecycle date (<meta-date>);
to name the format/medium of a document being cited as part of a bibliographic reference; or
to name the format/medium for an ISBN or similar identifier.

caption.title: In elements <date>, <element-citation>, <isbn>, <issn>, <meta-date>, <mixed-citation>, <nlm-citation>, <pub-date>, and <release-date>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The format for the publication of this standards document, for example, “print”, “online”, “epub”. This value is not constrained, so any standards organization is free to use the values it needs for processing.

sec.p: Type of publication identifier or the organization or system that defined the identifier for a non-standard citation, typically a reference to a technical report, book, journal article, etc.
This attribute is not used to name the type of cited standard for a <std> ; the <std> element used the @type attribute.
This attribute is used inside a bibliographic citation element such as <mixed-citation> or <element-citation> to identify what is being cited.

caption.title: In elements <element-citation>, <mixed-citation>, and <nlm-citation>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The type of identifier “doi” or name or type of organization that created the identifier “aggregator”.

sec.p: Type of publisher or publishing organization of a work being cited that is not a standard (for example, “government”, “university”, “commercial”, “foundation”, “private”, or “corporate”).
This attribute is not used to name the type of publisher for a cited standard (<std>).

caption.title: In elements <element-citation>, <mixed-citation>, and <nlm-citation>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: For citing works that are not standards, this attribute holds the type of publisher or publishing organization, for example, “government”.

sec.p: Identifies why this milestone exists, what problem it is solving, and/or what object cannot be modeled using the regular hierarchy.

caption.title: In elements <milestone-end> and <milestone-start>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The reason for a milestone or information about an object that cannot be modeled using the regular hierarchy.

sec.p: Type of element that is the target of the cross-reference (for example, a figure (“fig”), a table (“table”), or a footnote (“fn”). The values may be used for type-specific processing or validation.

caption.title: In element <xref>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Bibliographic reference (typically to a <ref> element, but it may point to a <element-citation> or an <mixed-citation> if there are multiple citations inside the <ref> element).
Figure or group of figures (to a <fig> or <fig-group> element).
List or list item (to a <list> or <list-item> element; also, possibly to a <def-list> or <def-item> element).
Table or group of tables (to a <table-wrap> or <table-wrap-group> element).

sec.p: Type of article being described by the <related-article> element.

caption.title: In element <related-article>, this attribute must be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The article type for the related article, for example, “announcement”.

sec.p: Describes the relationship between the related term (<related-term>) and the term (<term>) that is being defined in a term section using the <term-display> element. For example, the related term is a deprecated form of the term being defined.

caption.title: In element <related-term>, this attribute must be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The related term is the initial letters of the preferred term, or other combination pronounced as a word, rather than as a sequence of letters.
The related term is unlike the preferred term and provides a contrast.
The related term is not preferred and should not be used.
Someone looking for a term should use this related term instead of the term found.
Someone looking at the preferred term might also be interested in this related term.
The related term has a very similar meaning to the preferred term.

sec.p: Resolution of a bitmap in dots per inch, expressed as a decimal integer (for example, “72”, “300”).

caption.title: In element <glyph-data>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The number of dots per inch of the bitmap.

sec.p: Value of the identifier of an associated element; used for internal links of related elements. For example, an <xref> can point to the @id of a figure (<fig>).

caption.title: In element <index-term-range-end>, this attribute must be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Must point to an existing identifier within the standards document.

caption.title: In elements <milestone-end>, <milestone-start>, <nav-pointer>, and <related-term>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Points to the existing identifier within the standards document.

caption.title: In elements <aff>, <award-id>, <back>, <bio>, <contrib>, <def>, <editing-instruction>, <funding-source>, <named-content>, <see>, <see-also>, <see-also-entry>, <see-entry>, <sig>, <sig-block>, <term>, and <xref>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Points to one or more existing identifiers within the standards document.

sec.p: Table attribute used to request vertical spanning by naming the number of rows a cell spans in a vertical span. (This attribute is based on and intended to be converted easily to the XHMTL rowspan attribute.)

caption.title: In elements <td> and <th>, this attribute will be assigned the value 1 by default.

tr.td: How many rows this cell will span vertically, for example, “3”.

sec.p: Defines which rules to draw between the rows and columns of an XHTML 1.1 table. (This attribute is based on and intended to be converted easily to the XHMTL rules attribute.)

caption.title: In element <table>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Rules on all rows and columns.

sec.p: Specifies the cells for which the <td> element provides header information. This provides an alternative to using explicitly named header elements (<th>) if the arrangement of header cells is not complex. (This attribute is based on and intended to be converted easily to the XHMTL scope attribute.)

caption.title: In elements <td> and <th>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Provides header information for the rest of a column.
Provides header information for the rest of a column group (i.e., the remaining cells within the <colgroup> element).
Provides header information for the rest of a row.
Provides header information for the rest of a row group (i.e., the remaining cells of the current <thead>, <tfoot>, or <tbody>).

sec.p: Used to record the type of semantic content included in the section (for example, “foreword”, “terms”, or “scope”).

caption.title: In elements <sec> and <term-sec>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Names the main semantic type of the section content, such as “scope”. This is not a restricted list; the attribute may take any value.

sec.p: Sequence number of a document within the type of sequence named by the element to which this attribute is attached: on a <volume> element, the sequence within the volume; on an <issue> element, the sequence within the issue; on an <fpage> element, the sequence within a single page; and on an <elocation-id> element, the electronic sequence.

caption.title: In elements <elocation-id>, <fpage>, <issue>, and <volume>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The number of the document in a sequence of documents within a volume, issue, electronic compilation, or even on the same page.

sec.p: Provide an alternative version of the index entry for use as a sort key, for example, an ASCII version replacing an accented character with an unaccented one.

caption.title: In element <index-entry>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: A version of the index entry for sorting

sec.p: Identifier of a journal, book, conference proceedings, or other publication that is (or contains) the target of the <related-object>.

caption.title: In element <related-object>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The identifier of the source for the <related-object>.

sec.p: Type of source identifier (for example, a DOI, ISSN, ISBN, or publisher’s identifier) for a <related-object>.

caption.title: In element <related-object>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The type of identifier that names the source of the related object, for example, a DOI.
The type of document identifier named in the @source-id attribute for a (<related-object>) element. This attribute qualifies the @source-id attribute.

sec.p: This attribute can be used with two elements:

list-item.p: to identify the kind of source providing an award that sponsored a work or the research on which a work was based (with the element <funding-source>)
to identify the type of publication, for example, a “book”, “guide”, or “database” that is (or contains) the target of the <related-object>.

caption.title: In element <funding-source>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Type of entity (such as an organization or an individual) that is the source of an award which sponsors a work or the research underlying the work.

caption.title: In element <related-object>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The type of object named in the related object (<related-object>) element, for example, a “database”.

sec.p: The number of columns that will share the <col> or <colgroup> element’s attributes. (This attribute is based on and intended to be converted easily to the XHMTL span attribute.)

caption.title: In elements <col> and <colgroup>, this attribute will be assigned the value 1 by default.

tr.td: How many columns will have the same attributes, for example, “3”.

sec.p: Specifies distinctions in the applicability of a particular element.
This Tag Set does not limit the uses of the @specific-use attribute. As examples, @specific-use could be used to mark content (such as a paragraph, note, or section) that:

list-item.p: Is intended for organization internal use or Working Group use only;
Only appears in one format (“web-only”, “print-only”, “voice-only”, “electronic-only”); or
Contains an accessibility alternative that screen readers could “read” but that visual display devices would ignore. (See also the @alt attribute.)

caption.title:
In elements , , , , ,
, , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , ,

, , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , <toc>, <toc-div>, <toc-entry>, <toc-group>, <trans-source>, <trans-subtitle>, <trans-title>, <trans-title-group>, <underline>, <uri>, <verse-group>, <verse-line>, <version>, <volume>, <volume-id>, <volume-series>, <xref>, and <year>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: A specific distinction in the applicability of a particular element, for example, “print-only”.

sec.p: Date on which the document starts being “free-to-read” or begins the given license, as defined in NISO RP-22-2015, Access License and Indicators.

caption.title: In elements <ali:free_to_read> and <ali:license_ref>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The ISO 8601 date on which the document starts being “free-to-read” or begins the given license.

sec.p: In ISO STS, this attribute named the designator for the standard being cited (in the element <std>). Current NISO STS Best Practice does not use this attribute; rather the identifier for a standard being cited should be tagged either

list-item.p: in a <std-id> element (for a single identifier, equivalent to this attribute) or, more typically,
using the element <std-id-group> which holds several standard identifiers (<std-id>), for example, both a dated and an undated designator.

caption.title: In element <std>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Provides the designator for the standard being cited (in element <std>), but Best Practice is not to use this attribute. (See Best Practice above.)

sec.p: Names the type of link that the <std-id> contains, for example, a DOI

caption.title: In element <std-id>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The type of link that the <std-id> contains, for example, a DOI

sec.p: What type of identifier is named in the <std-id> element, for example, “dated”.

caption.title: In element <std-id>, this attribute must be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The type of identifier expressed in a <std-id> element, for example, “undated” or “short”.

sec.p: Identifies the type of standards body (international, national, SDO, consortia, etc.) that is creating or adopting this standard.

caption.title: In elements <std-doc-meta> and <std-meta>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The type of standards body producing or adopting this standard, for example, “international”, “sdo”, “consortia”, etc. There is no fixed list; standards organizations will self-identify.

sec.p: Used on the <std-org> element, which can name a nested hierarchy, to indicate the level of nesting standards bodies. Such groups start at “1”, with embedded groups taking higher numbers.

caption.title: In element <std-org>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Typically a counting number that names the level, such as “1”.

sec.p: The <std-org> element holds name and location information for one of the standards organizations responsible for publishing or adopting the standard. What part that standards organization played in the production or adoption of the standard can be described with this attribute, for example, “lead”, “co-producer”, “co-publisher”.

caption.title: In element <std-org>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: What part the standards organization played in producing or adopting this standard, for example, “lead”, “co-producer”, etc.

sec.p: The type of standards organization that is named in the <std-org> element, for example, an international standards body or an SDO.

caption.title: In elements <std-doc-meta>, <std-meta>, and <std-org>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The type of standards organization named in the <std-org> element, for example, “sdo”.

sec.p: Name of the lifecycle stage or type of the designators contained in a <std-id> element or in a group of such elements within a <std-id-group>. There may be many such standard identifiers, differentiated by this attribute.

caption.title: In elements <std-id> and <std-id-group>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The lifecycle stage or type of the <std-id> elements, for example, “std-as-published” or “std-family or the lifecycle stage or type for a group of <std-id> elements (<std-id-group>).”

sec.p: Names a standards lifecycle event (document type) that extends or modifies a base standard (i.e., the undated designation)

caption.title: In element <release-date>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The name of the lifecycle event named by this date.

sec.p: Names the concrete style or rendering to be applied to the element. This attribute can be used in several contexts:

list-item.p: with the styled content element (<styled-content>), records XHTML classes or similar styling information;
with many of the elements within a NISO JATS table (<table>), records the name of the style to be applied to the element.

caption.title: In elements <caption>, <col>, <colgroup>, <table>, <tbody>, <td>, <tfoot>, <th>, <thead>, and <tr>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Names the markup style for one of the elements within a table or for the entire table.

caption.title: In element <styled-content>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Names the inline markup style for the element.

sec.p: Description or explanation of the stylistic difference being recorded (for example, illuminated letters, drop cap).

caption.title:
In elements

and , this attribute may be used if the element is used.

sec.p: General subject, discipline, field of study, or information class of a particular <subj-group> element.

caption.title: In element <subj-group>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

sec.p: A summary of the contents or the semantics of the table, provided for speech-synthesis and non-visual browsers. (This attribute is based on and intended to be converted easily to the XHMTL summary attribute.)

caption.title: In element <table>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Textual description of the contents of a table, intended to be read to the audience for the table.

sec.p: Type of supplement or the reason for the supplement (for example, “conference” for a supplement containing information from a conference or symposium).

caption.title: In element <supplement>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The type or reason for the supplement, for example, “conference” or “issue”.

sec.p: Stores the symbol (for example, an asterisk, numeral, section mark) that was displayed in the original document to identify a specific footnote, if this symbol is to be preserved.

caption.title: In elements <collab> and <fn>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The symbol, such as a dagger “†”, used to mark a footnote or inclusion in a collaboration.

sec.p: Kind of <target> that has been created (for example, describes the reason why some portion of text has been designated for cross-references purposes).

caption.title: In element <target>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Names/describes the rationale for designating a portion of text for cross-reference.

sec.p: The current status of a term (<term> inside a <term-display>) in a terms and definitions section, for example, “deprecated”.

caption.title: In element <term>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: A term that does not meet the requirements to be a preferred term, but is not deprecated, possibly because it is in common use. Expanded and abbreviated forms of a term are sometimes used as admitted terms.
This term is deprecated in favor of a preferred term. Deprecated terms include obsolete and superseded terms.
This term is the one to be used.

sec.p: The type of term (<term> inside a <term-display>) in a terms and definitions section, for example, “acronym”.

caption.title: In element <term>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The term is the full form of a word or phrase.

sec.p: Specifies if the styling of the element it modifies should act as a toggle-switch. When the toggle-switch is on, the textual content of the element will always be visually set apart from its context. When the switch is off, the rendition is fixed to the style requested and will not change based on context.

caption.title: In element <italic>, this attribute will be assigned the value yes by default.

tr.td: The element does not act as a toggle; the emphasized text remains in the requested style, no matter what the surrounding text does.

The emphasis element acts as a toggle. If the surrounding text is set to the same emphasis style, the text within this element will change to another emphasis style, so that the text will always be typographically distinct from its surroundings.

caption.title: In element <roman>, this attribute will be assigned the value no by default.

tr.td: The element does not act as a toggle; the emphasized text remains in the same emphasis, no matter what the surrounding text does.

The emphasis element acts as a toggle. If the surrounding text is set to the same emphasis, the text within this element will change to another emphasis style, so that the text will always be typographically distinct from its surroundings.

caption.title: In elements <bold>, <monospace>, <overline>, <sans-serif>, <sc>, <strike>, <styled-content>, and <underline>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The element does not act as a toggle; the emphasized text remains in the same emphasis, no matter what the surrounding text does.

The emphasis element acts as a toggle. If the surrounding text is set to the same emphasis, the text within this element will change to another emphasis style, so that the text will always be typographically distinct from its surroundings.

sec.p: Provides type or kind classing for the content of its element. The values for this attribute vary depending on the element to which the attribute is attached.

caption.title: In element <meta-date>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Names, for example, a lifecycle stage that should not be expressed with <release-date> or a circumstance that is unique to a particular standards organization, for example, “Date of Issuance” for ASME or “Date of ratification” for CEN-CENELEC. There are no suggested values for this attribute. The attribute @type is retained for backwards compatibility with ISO STS. Best Practice for new documents is to use the @date-type attribute instead of the @type attribute to record this information.

caption.title: In element <std>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The standard being cited is a specific dated version of a standard.
The standard being cited is a multipart standard.
The standard being cited is a standard without a specifying date.

caption.title: In element <std-ref>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The standard designator is a dated version of a standard.
The standard designator is a short form of the standard designator.
The standard designator does not include a specifying date.

caption.title: In element <std-xref>, this attribute must be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The type of standard to which this cross-reference is pointing, for example, a value of “supersedes” would indicate that this cross-reference points to the standard that the current standard supersedes.

sec.p: Style of underline to be used (for example, “single”, “double”, “dashed”).

caption.title: In element <underline>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The style of underlining requested; for example, “double” would mean underlined by two rules, very close together.

sec.p: The units of measure in which the size or length of a cited work is expressed (for example, a @units value might record “pages”, “minutes”, “seconds”, or “linear-feet”).

caption.title: In element <size>, this attribute must be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Names the units of measure in which the size is expressed, for example, “MB”.

sec.p: Sets the vertical alignment inside a table cell. (This attribute is based on and intended to be converted easily to the XHMTL valign attribute.)

caption.title: In elements <col>, <colgroup>, <tbody>, <td>, <tfoot>, <th>, <thead>, and <tr>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: All cells in the same row as a cell whose @valign attribute has this value should have their textual data positioned so that the first text line occurs on a baseline common to all cells in the row. This constraint does not apply to subsequent text lines in these cells.
Cell data is flush with the bottom of the cell.
Cell data is centered vertically within the cell.
Cell data is flush with the top of the cell.

sec.p: Version of TeX or LaTeX used to produce the mathematics.

caption.title: In element <tex-math>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Version of TeX or LaTeX used in the equation.

sec.p: The name of a controlled vocabulary (defined formally) or a generic vocabulary (subject area defined informally), taxonomy, ontology, database, term list, thesaurus, index, etc. that is the source of the term.

caption.title: In elements <ics-wrap>, <kwd-group>, <named-content>, <role>, <subj-group>, and <term>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The name of the vocabulary, taxonomy, ontology, database, term list, index, etc. that is the source of the term named in the element’s content.

sec.p: Unique identifier of the controlled vocabulary, taxonomy, ontology, database, thesaurus, index, etc. that is the source of the terms in a group of terms such as a keywords group or subject group. The content is typically (but not limited to) a URI or DOI.

caption.title: In elements <ics-wrap>, <kwd-group>, <named-content>, <role>, <subj-group>, and <term>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: A unique identifier of the source of the term named in the element content. This is typically a URI or DOI, but it may be any identifier.

sec.p: The canonical form of the term. (Note: The content of the element to which this attribute is attached is the free prose version of the vocabulary or taxonomic term. The @vocab-term attribute holds a canonical version of the same term, as it appears in the vocabulary. For example, if the attribute value was “digitized-vor”, the element might contain the display text “Digitized Version of Record”.)

caption.title: In elements <compound-kwd>, <compound-subject>, <ics>, <ics-desc>, <kwd>, <named-content>, <nested-kwd>, <role>, <subject>, and <term>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The canonical form of the term as it exists in the named vocabulary.

sec.p: Unique identifier of the term to which this attribute is attached within a specific vocabulary, such as (but not limited to) an item number, a URI, DOI, etc.

caption.title: In elements <compound-kwd>, <compound-subject>, <ics>, <ics-desc>, <kwd>, <named-content>, <nested-kwd>, <role>, <subject>, and <term>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: A unique identifier of the term within a particular vocabulary, taxonomy, ontology, database, index, etc. This is typically a URI or DOI, but it may be any identifier, for example, an item number.

sec.p: Volume of the journal in which a related journal article exists.
The @vol attribute can be used, along with the @journal-id, @issue, and @page attributes, to provide the metadata for a related journal article.

caption.title: In element <related-article>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The journal volume number for a related journal article, for example, “3” for the third volume, “125” for the one hundred and twenty-fifth, or “XV” for the fifteenth.

sec.p: This attribute can be used within a NISO JATS table (based on and designed to be converted easily to the XHTML 1.1 table model) to specify component width (as defined in the XHTML 1.1 table model to take advantage of existing software for table handling).

caption.title: In elements <col>, <colgroup>, and <table>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: Within the NISO JATS Table model (<table>), the width of the table. By default, the JATS table model (based on and designed to be converted easily to the XHTML 1.1 table model) should be used as defined in the XHTML 1.1 table model, to take advantage of existing software for table handling.

sec.p: The pixels per row in the bit-mapped glyph that has been declared with a <glyph-data> element as part of a <private-char> element.

caption.title: In element <glyph-data>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: An integer number of pixels, for example, “45”, that is the number of pixels in each row of the bitmap of the <glyph-data> element.

sec.p: The intended behavior for an XLink link when activated by an application, specifically, the timing for obtaining or retrieving the content of a link (for example, by a user clicking on the link to request the material, or by the material being automatically loaded with a document when the document or document component is loaded).

caption.title: In elements <abbrev>, <app>, <bio>, <chem-struct>, <collab>, <contrib>, <custom-meta>, <element-citation>, <email>, <ext-link>, <funding-source>, <graphic>, <inline-graphic>, <inline-supplementary-material>, <institution>, <issue-id>, <license>, <long-desc>, <media>, <mixed-citation>, <named-content>, <nlm-citation>, <pronunciation>, <pub-id>, <related-article>, <self-uri>, <supplementary-material>, <uri>, and <volume-id>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The behavior is unconstrained, and no other markup is generally available in the link to assist an application in deducing the retrieval mechanism.
An application should retrieve the link at the same time a user obtains the initial document load.
An application should only retrieve the link after a user has physically triggered the retrieval, for example, clicked on the link.
The behavior is unconstrained, but other markup is generally available in the link to assist an application in deducing the retrieval mechanism.

sec.p: An address or identifier that permits an XLink application to find a remote resource, for example, a URI (such as a URL or filename) that links to an online site associated with the author or the online definition of a term. As specified in XML Linking Language (XLink) Version 1.0, the value of an @xlink:href must be a valid URI. (See https://www.w3.org/TR/xlink/)

caption.title: In elements <graphic>, <inline-graphic>, and <media>, this attribute must be used if the element is used.

tr.td: A pointer (which may be a URL) to a resource.

caption.title: In elements <abbrev>, <app>, <bio>, <chem-struct>, <collab>, <contrib>, <custom-meta>, <element-citation>, <email>, <ext-link>, <funding-source>, <inline-supplementary-material>, <institution>, <issue-id>, <license>, <long-desc>, <mixed-citation>, <named-content>, <nlm-citation>, <pronunciation>, <pub-id>, <related-article>, <self-uri>, <supplementary-material>, <uri>, and <volume-id>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: A pointer (which may be a URL) to a resource.

sec.p: A URI reference pointing to some resource that describes the role or function of an XLink link.

caption.title: In elements <abbrev>, <app>, <bio>, <chem-struct>, <collab>, <contrib>, <custom-meta>, <element-citation>, <email>, <ext-link>, <funding-source>, <graphic>, <inline-graphic>, <inline-supplementary-material>, <institution>, <issue-id>, <license>, <long-desc>, <media>, <mixed-citation>, <named-content>, <nlm-citation>, <pronunciation>, <pub-id>, <related-article>, <self-uri>, <supplementary-material>, <uri>, and <volume-id>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The URI of a resource that describes the role, reason, or rationale for the link.

sec.p: The intended presentation behavior for an XLink link, specifically the manner in which the content of a link will be displayed, for example, as embedded material or in a separate window.

caption.title: In elements <abbrev>, <app>, <bio>, <chem-struct>, <collab>, <contrib>, <custom-meta>, <element-citation>, <email>, <ext-link>, <funding-source>, <graphic>, <inline-graphic>, <inline-supplementary-material>, <institution>, <issue-id>, <license>, <long-desc>, <media>, <mixed-citation>, <named-content>, <nlm-citation>, <pronunciation>, <pub-id>, <related-article>, <self-uri>, <supplementary-material>, <uri>, and <volume-id>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The link should be displayed as part of the initial document being viewed, i.e., the material will be “embedded” directly into the initial document.
The link should be displayed as a new, separate window, frame, pane, or other presentation context.
The presentation behavior is unconstrained, and no other markup is generally available in the link to assist an application in deducing the display mechanism.
The presentation behavior is unconstrained, but other markup is generally available in the link to assist an application in deducing the display mechanism.
The link should be displayed in the same window, frame, pane, or other presentation context as the initial document, thereby “replacing” the document or other object being linked.

sec.p: Describes the function of an XLink link’s remote resource in human-readable fashion.

caption.title: In elements <abbrev>, <app>, <bio>, <chem-struct>, <collab>, <contrib>, <custom-meta>, <element-citation>, <email>, <ext-link>, <funding-source>, <graphic>, <inline-graphic>, <inline-supplementary-material>, <institution>, <issue-id>, <license>, <long-desc>, <media>, <mixed-citation>, <named-content>, <nlm-citation>, <pronunciation>, <pub-id>, <related-article>, <self-uri>, <supplementary-material>, <uri>, and <volume-id>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: A descriptive, human-readable title that acts as a brief description of the link.

sec.p: The kind of XLink link used with an element. For all elements in this Tag Set that can take links (except the <mml:math> element), this attribute may be either omitted; or it must be set to the word “simple”, which means that the link is a simple, one-ended link.

caption.title: In elements <abbrev>, <app>, <bio>, <chem-struct>, <collab>, <contrib>, <custom-meta>, <element-citation>, <email>, <ext-link>, <funding-source>, <graphic>, <inline-graphic>, <inline-supplementary-material>, <institution>, <issue-id>, <license>, <long-desc>, <media>, <mixed-citation>, <named-content>, <nlm-citation>, <pronunciation>, <pub-id>, <related-article>, <self-uri>, <supplementary-material>, <uri>, and <volume-id>, this attribute must have the value simple (as given below).

tr.td: The link is an XML simple (one-ended) link.

sec.p: Provides a base URI for identifiers in the XML-tagged standards document or a part of an XML-tagged standards document. Within this standards document, or a portion of the document, all URIs are assumed to be built on the “base” provided as the value of this attribute. For example, if a document has an @xml:base of “https://mulberrytech.com/”, a URI inside the document of “scope/rationale.html” would be processed as if it were “https://mulberrytech.com/scope/rationale.html”. Values of @xml:base are inherited from the closest base, meaning that if there is an @xml:base on a document and on a part of the document, uses inside the part of the document take the value of the part, not the whole.

caption.title:
In elements , , , , , ,
, , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , ,
, , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , ,

sec.p: The language of the intellectual content of the element for which this is an attribute. This attribute may be set on many elements, including the two document elements (<standard> and <adoption>) and the values are inherited by all the element’ children, unless overridden explicitly.

caption.title: In elements <adoption>, <part-of-speech>, <pronunciation>, <related-term>, <standard>, <term-display>, and <term-source>, this attribute will be assigned the value en by default.

tr.td: An alphanumeric string, which may include hyphens
An abbreviation for a natural language (such as “en” for English or “de” for German) or for a language and a script (“ja-Kana”).

caption.title:
In elements , , , ,
, , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , ,

tr.td: An alphanumeric string, which may include hyphens
An abbreviation for a natural language (such as “en” for English or “de” for German) or for a language and a script (“ja-Kana”).

sec.p: When printing or displaying the associated element, all white space (such as tabs, ordinary spaces, and line breaks) should be preserved.

caption.title: In elements <code>, <glyph-data>, and <preformat>, this attribute must have the value preserve (as given below).

tr.td: White space should be preserved. (This value is fixed and cannot be changed in a document.)

title.named-content: NISO ALI Namespace (NISO Access License and Indicators)

sec.p: This is not an attribute, but the namespace pseudo-attribute. The value provides a prefix and URI to use for the ALI (NISO Access License and Indicators) elements. All namespace prefixes must be associated with a URL, and the prefix “ali” has been set to the URL https://www.niso.org/schemas/ali/1.0 as per the NISO ALI Best Practices recommendation.

caption.title: In elements <adoption>, <ali:free_to_read>, <ali:license_ref>, and <standard>, this attribute must have the value http://www.niso.org/schemas/ali/1.0 (as given below).

tr.td: The URI named in the NISO Access License and Indicators for the ALI elements.

sec.p: This is not an attribute, but the namespace pseudo-attribute. The value provides a prefix and URI to use for the MathML elements. All namespace prefixes must be associated with a URL, and the prefix “mml” has been set to the URL for the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) MathML Tag Set.

caption.title: In elements <adoption>, <app>, <app-group>, <mml:math>, and <standard>, this attribute must have the value http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML (as given below).

tr.td: The prefix “mml” has been set to the URL for the W3C MathML Tag Set.

sec.p: This is not an attribute, but the namespace pseudo-attribute. The value provides the URI to use for the OASIS Exchange (CALS) table element. All namespace prefixes must be associated with a URL, and the OASIS table namespace prefix has been set to “oasis”.

caption.title: In elements <adoption> and <standard>, this attribute must have the value http://www.niso.org/standards/z39-96/ns/oasis-exchange/table (as given below).

tr.td: The URI used for the prefix “oasis” to use OASIS Exchange (CALS) tables in the standards document.

sec.p: This is not an attribute, but the namespace pseudo-attribute. The value provides a prefix and URI to use for the TBX elements. All namespace prefixes must be associated with a URL.

caption.title: In elements <adoption>, <app>, <app-group>, and <standard>, this attribute must have the value urn:iso:std:iso:30042:ed-1 (as given below).

tr.td: The URI that goes with the “tbx” prefix

sec.p: This is not an attribute, but the namespace pseudo-attribute. The value provides a namespace prefix and URI to use for the XInclude elements. All namespace prefixes must be associated with a URL, and the prefix “xi” has been set to the URL for the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) XInclude Recommendation.

caption.title: In elements <adoption>, <app>, <app-group>, <standard>, <xi:fallback>, and <xi:include>, this attribute must have the value http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude (as given below).

tr.td: The prefix “xi” has been set to the URL for the W3C XInclude Recommendation.

sec.p: This is not an attribute, but the namespace pseudo-attribute. The value provides a URI to use for the XLink linking attributes (which has been set to a prefix of “xlink”). All namespace prefixes must be associated with a URL, and the prefix “xlink” has been set to the URL for the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) XLink Recommendation.

caption.title: In elements <abbrev>, <adoption>, <app>, <bio>, <chem-struct>, <collab>, <contrib>, <custom-meta>, <element-citation>, <email>, <ext-link>, <funding-source>, <graphic>, <inline-graphic>, <inline-supplementary-material>, <institution>, <issue-id>, <license>, <long-desc>, <media>, <mixed-citation>, <named-content>, <nlm-citation>, <pronunciation>, <pub-id>, <related-article>, <self-uri>, <standard>, <supplementary-material>, <uri>, and <volume-id>, this attribute must have the value http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink (as given below).

tr.td: The prefix “xlink” has been set to the URL for the W3C XLink Recommendation.

sec.p: This is not an attribute, but a namespace pseudo-attribute. The value provides a URI to use for the @xsi_schemaLocation attribute. All namespace prefixes must be associated with a URL, and the prefix “xsi” has been set to the URL for the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) XML Schema.

caption.title: In elements <adoption> and <standard>, this attribute must have the value http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance (as given below).

tr.td: The prefix “xsi” has been set to the URL for W3C XML Schema.

sec.p: When the attribute @parse is set to XML (parse="xml"), the XPointer contained in this attribute is evaluated to identify a portion of the resource to include. This attribute is optional; when omitted, the entire resource is included. See the W3C XInclude documentation: https://www.w3.org/TR/xinclude/

caption.title: In element <xi:include>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: XPointer pointing to a portion of a resource

sec.p: The number of rows in the bit-mapped glyph that has been declared with a <glyph-data> element as part of a <private-char> element.

caption.title: In element <glyph-data>, this attribute may be used if the element is used.

tr.td: The number of rows (for example, “25”) used to define the glyph in a <glyph-data> element.
